subject: Ethics
title: Cookies and Consent Theater
description: A quick, practical guide to Cookies and Consent Theater.

hook.text: Every website asks you to 'accept cookies.' Most people click OK without reading. That's the point.

buildup.text: Cookie consent banners were supposed to give users control. Instead, they became an exercise in exhaustion.

discovery.text: Researchers found that 'reject all' buttons are deliberately harder to find, smaller, or buried in menus.

twist.text: One study showed only 11% of consent banners actually comply with GDPR. The rest are legal theater.

climax.text: Consent designed to be bypassed isn't consent. It's a rubber stamp disguised as a choice.

punchline.text: Clicking 'I agree' isn't agreement if refusal was never easy.

quiz.question: Why do critics call cookie consent banners 'consent theater'?
options: Banners make websites load much slower
Cookies are always harmless to users
Reject options are often designed to be hard to use
